Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:53CC-D651-DYG3-11PD-00000-00WILLIS REPORT for July 21, 20112011-07-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:25ZLexisNexisTHE WILLIS REPORT5:00 PM ESTRichard Shelby, Lakshman Achuthan, Susan Solovic, Ben Jarkesy, Ben Ferguson, John UlzheimerNEWSDomestic072101cb.222WILLIS REPORT for July 21, 2011Gerri Willis, Joe Trippi, Fred Barnes

GERRI WILLIS, HOST: Hi everyone and welcome. I'm Gerri Willis.

Tonight who's got billions of dollars in cash and won't spend a dime? My "Two Cents" in just a minute and as Dodd-Frank turns a year-old I'll be joined by the top Republican on the Senate Banking Committee. He says the law killed American jobs. And he tells us how we can fix it.

Another bad jobs report today. Why is the economy acting like this? We'll investigate how to break out of that cycle and "Oh Canada", what are they doing so right that we seem to be doing oh so wrong? All that and more tonight on THE WILLIS REPORT.

Deal or no deal? That's what we've been focused on all week, waiting for, hoping for some resolution to the debt ceiling debate and we're all praying it happens before we trip a default or a credit downgrade. We're paralyzed, not just in Washington but all over the country. A report today, major companies are sitting on piles, piles of cash, money they haven't deployed for any productive use.

GE, that's the company whose CEO advises the president on jobs, has more than $83 billion at its disposal, just sitting there. Johnson & Johnson with nearly 22.5 billion, tech companies too, Apple and Oracle each sitting on $16 billion, Dell with 14. All money that could go to reinvestment, finding new cures, new technologies putting people to work, but we, we're stuck in a rut with no plan to go forward on jobs or the debt and today the final space shuttle mission, Atlantis, returned to earth, capping a 30-year, 135-mission lifespan.

No plan for how we might pursue the next frontier or even whether we want to. Deal or no deal, it's time we found one for jobs and the economy before one is forced on us that we might not like, but that's my "Two Cents". More on the debate on the debt coming at the bottom of the hour, but first a not so happy birthday today, the financial regulation law known as Dodd-Frank is celebrating its first birthday today and with it comes a new consumer financial protection bureau that Republicans are fighting tooth and nail.

One of those opponents, the ranking member of the Senate Banking Committee, Richard Shelby of Alabama joins me now -- great to see you, Senator.

SEN. RICHARD SHELBY (R), ALABAMA: Thank you, Gerri.

WILLIS: Well we listened in on you a little today in your meeting, your committee meeting on the Dodd-Frank bill and particularly interested in the conversation you had with Barney Frank who helped author that bill. Here is what the two of you had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If you remember and I remember that in 2005 and six (INAUDIBLE), but as I remember the major opponent at that point was my Republican (INAUDIBLE) Mr. Oxley (ph) that he had a very different bill and there was a -- Mr. Oxley --

SHELBY: He had a weaker bill.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right. In fact Mr. Oxley said --

SHELBY: You might have helped him with it?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: All right, so tell me what you made of that hearing. And did anything get done or was it just an opportunity to go over the bill itself?

SHELBY: Well, I think it was a good opportunity to go over the bill itself. Actually nothing done yet but a lot of things need to be done to the Dodd-Frank act. I pointed that out before. It was rushed to judgment and rushed to passage. Now they're rushing to put forth a lot of regulations. It is going to affect the whole economy in this country. I think we need to go back and look at it, especially the structure of how the top bureaucrat was put together.

WILLIS: Well, you know, it's interesting, Tim Geithner not too long ago said that the purpose of this law, get this, it was designed to lay a stronger foundation for innovation, economic growth and get this, job creation. How's that working out?

SHELBY: Well, as I pointed out this morning, I took Secretary Geithner's own words, and used them for a few minutes. It certainly has not spawned economic growth or job creation. It has spawned a huge bureaucracy and it is going to be interfering with the market. It is going to impede the creation of jobs. And we don't know how much power these people are going to have in the future. What we need are honestly, good consumer rules and so forth.

We all advocate that. We're all for that, but we don't need to create a czar, a consumer czar that is accountable to nobody. This is horrible. Not accountable to the Congress for funding. Not accountable to a board of governance or anything. So that's what we're trying to change. And we have sent the word, the 43 Republicans, so we're not going to confirm anybody to that job unless there's a change in this structure. I hope that the administration is listening to that.

WILLIS: All right. Well just to synopsize the changes that the GOP wants in the consumer bureau which is sort of the heart of your criticism here, establish a board of directors, subject the bureau to an appropriations process because right now they can get pretty much any money they want. Establish a safety and soundness check --

SHELBY: Absolutely.

WILLIS: So you really want controls in place. You don't want this bureau to just go off willy-nilly and do whatever they want. Right now, still a system of checks and balances.

SHELBY: Absolutely. All we're talking about is a common sense balance to this huge, powerful bureaucracy. We should have had it last year. We didn't have the votes but we're getting toward it now. And we're saying to the administration, we'll work together with you on this. We're not trying to change the mission of the consumer agency. We're trying to change the structure and to make it accountable.

WILLIS: Well, it's been laughable when you look at the entirety of Dodd-Frank how long it has taken to implement. It is not implemented in any way yet. Some 122 deadlines have been missed. Only 12 percent of 400 rule-making requirements have been completed. What does that tell you?

SHELBY: Well, it tells you that what Dodd-Frank basically is, is a horror movie, a horror movie for the American economy, a horror movie for if people are interested in taking risks and creating jobs because there is so much uncertainty out there because of what this through regulatory process this could mean to every business, financial, non-banks and so forth in this country.

WILLIS: All right. If you look at the cost, General Accountability Office just came out with estimates of the cost of implementing this thing. And it looks like it's going to be about a billion dollars, the biggest cost, bar none, that Consumer Financial Protection Bureau that you mentioned. It will cost almost 500,000 to put into place. Tell me, are you opposed to protecting consumers or do you just not like the structure of this organization?

SHELBY: Gerri, we're all consumers. We want to protect the consumers and also create products for consumers, but we don't want to create a bureaucracy that is unaccountable to the Congress for its funding, unaccountable even in governance to anyone. Creating a bureaucracy with a powerful czar there that could really impede the growth of our economy in the future.

WILLIS: You know, just to underline your points about the bureaucracy on this thing, if you look at all of Dodd-Frank, if you took all those pages it would fill 2.5 times an Empire State Building, all the paper from this thing. And it is 16 times -- it would take 16 Moby Dick novels to contain all of the Dodd-Frank rules and regulations. This thing is huge. It is leviathan. Do we really have any idea what the ultimate impact of these law changes will be?

SHELBY: Gerri, you say it very well. This is going to be a nightmare. Already it is beginning to be a bad dream but it will be a nightmare for American business.

WILLIS: Well, Senator Shelby thanks for your time today.

SHELBY: Thank you, Gerri.

WILLIS: We really appreciate it. And our coverage of the Dodd-Frank anniversary continues later in the hour. John Ulzheimer will be here with how the law impacts your credit score.

And when we come back, jobless claims were up again today, so when can our economy break out of this losing cycle. And take a look at the stocks today; you're not going to believe it. No recession there. The Dow up 152 points -- why -- strong corporate earnings. We'll be right back.

WILLIS: More disappointing news on the jobs front today. Jobless claims unexpectedly jumped as companies lay off employees at a level not seen in nearly a year. Also which major companies are sitting on almost a trillion dollars in cash, when they could be, oh, you know, using it to hire and grow the economy? Stay tuned.

WILLIS: The latest jobs report released today -- surprised -- not a very good report. Also companies laying off employees at a level not seen in nearly a year. New claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly rose last week by 10,000, to 418,000. It isn't until weekly claims figures fall below the psychologically important 400,000 level that the economy is considered to be on the right track.

Lakshman Achuthan is the cofounder and COO of the Economic Cycle Research Institute, specializing in forecasting recessions and recoveries. We'll get to that in a second. But you know I just said the psychologically important level of 400,000.

LAKSHMAN ACHUTHAN, ECONOMIC CYCLE RESEARCH INSTITUTE COO: UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

WILLIS: Why? Why is it so important and why can't we get below that.

ACHUTHAN: Well I think it is important, it's a nice round number and the market likes to fixate on something and you know make all kinds of nice charts. I wouldn't put too much stock in the number but that doesn't mean I'm not worried. I'm worried. I think a lot of the story that you're hearing is that there's going to be the second-half rebound after we get past the disruption of the Japanese earthquake. And to be sure you're going to see a little firming in some factory jobs but the problem is most of us don't work in factories. Most of us work in the service sector. You know the vast majority of us work --

WILLIS: And that's not coming back right now.

ACHUTHAN: It's not. In fact in the last couple of months we've got jobs growth in services at one-third the pace of what it was last spring.

WILLIS: Wow.

ACHUTHAN: And so that's a problem that you, you've got to -- it's a stretch to blame that on an earthquake in Japan. There is something more going on. And that's why your claims numbers are up in the 400's.

WILLIS: And what we've seen of course is that economists all over the country are ratcheting down their expectations for growth for the second half. So you've got to think it's going to be very difficult for employment to do much better. I want to ask you about one of the trends that we're seeing out there. People are unemployed longer and longer.

ACHUTHAN: Yes.

WILLIS: And in several states across the country now we have numbers on people who've been unemployed for -- out of work for more than a year. There are states where more than a third of the people fit that bill. And New Jersey, Georgia, Michigan, South Carolina, North Carolina, Illinois, Florida. What does this tell you?

ACHUTHAN: Well, first the slowdown is making those jobs claims numbers stay high. The long duration unemployed, over a year or more, this stuff is more related to -- we have a bubble burst. You know the housing sector bubble burst, so those construction jobs, you know, financial sector related housing stuff, that's not coming back anytime soon. And then, during this, in the panic that followed the crisis, you know, businesses were in survival mode. So they were just slashing jobs left and right. And what they found out is that they can get by using technology instead of people. And so today we have almost two million less clerical workers than we did just a couple of years ago. They have been replaced largely by technology.

WILLIS: Well, you know, we talk about unemployment. One of the cures of course would be if some of these big companies would hire people. But right now in fact we're seeing just the opposite. We're seeing tons of layoffs, this despite the fact that a lot of these companies are sitting on a ton of dough.

ACHUTHAN: Yes.

WILLIS: Let me give you some numbers here and I mentioned this at the top of the show. General Electric has $82 billion in cash --

(CROSSTALK)

WILLIS: Johnson & Johnson, 22; Oracle and Apple -- two big tech companies here -- 16 billion in cash; Dell, 14. I don't understand --

ACHUTHAN: Yes.

WILLIS: -- why these companies are so reluctant to go out, reinvest, invent new things, find cures for diseases. Why are they so skittish, scared? Why are they such wusses?

ACHUTHAN: Well there are two pieces to it. One is we're producing a lot more with a lot less people, right? So GDP, the size of the economy is bigger than it was just before the recession. However, seven million less people are working. And so the difference in there is part of the reason they have this pile of cash that they're sitting on and they would invest it I believe if they were afraid of business beating down their doors. And right now they're not afraid of that at all.

WILLIS: Yes.

ACHUTHAN: To the contrary, you know so if they were scared of like I can't meet my demand then they would invest in people. They would invest in factories, but to the contrary you have no less an authority than the Fed chairman. And I'm going to quote him here.

(CROSSTALK)

ACHUTHAN: He says, when he is talking about the economic outlook he says, you know, there's an awful lot of uncertainty. That is the Fed chairman a couple of days ago. So if you're one of these companies, you say, I think I'm going to hang on to my cash for a little while just in case.

WILLIS: Yes, maybe he should be having those big press conferences. You know I know they're really popular but --

ACHUTHAN: More transparency, but --

WILLIS: All right, I have to ask you this quickly --

ACHUTHAN: Yes.

WILLIS: -- not a lot of time left. Are we going into another recession right now?

ACHUTHAN: Right now --

WILLIS: You're the expert --

ACHUTHAN: -- definitely go into another one. Right now that is the focus of all the work that we're doing. I don't have anything to report on that yet. I think it may be too early to tell, but we're working on it and I think we can make a call one way or another in the fall.

WILLIS: All right, we'll --

(CROSSTALK)

ACHUTHAN: -- the slow down -- here's the bad part. The slowdown is going to continue. It is not a soft patch.

WILLIS: Right.

ACHUTHAN: It's going to persist I think at least through the end of the year.

WILLIS: All right, well Lakshman you've got to come back --

ACHUTHAN: I will.

WILLIS: -- and continue to report on this for us. We really appreciate hearing from you.

ACHUTHAN: Thank you.

WILLIS: Coming up, what is Canada doing so right that we're apparently doing so wrong? And can we learn a lesson from one of our northern neighbors? We absolutely can. That's coming up next.

WILLIS: If President Obama needs more proof spending cuts, not higher taxes are the way to get this economy moving he doesn't have to look very far. Canada now has faster growth rates than the United States and a lower unemployment rate as well. There is something even more amazing about Canada's turnaround. Stay with us.

WILLIS: What's the old saying, history repeats itself? Well that is especially true when it comes to politics. And it's what we take from that history that counts. And people in Washington, they have short memories. They're either not familiar with our friends to the north or they don't care. I'm talking of course about Canada.

That country has been through what we are struggling through now and survived. Let's do a compare and contrast. We'll look at Canada circa 1993 and the U.S. today. According to Fred Barnes of "The Weekly Standard" who is going to join us in just a couple of moments back then Canada's government spending skyrocketed to more than 50 percent of the economy up from under 30 percent back in 1960.

Here it is more than 60 percent and could top 70 percent next year. And government debt in Canada was nearly 70 percent of GDP. Here we're topping 90 percent. The newly-elected government at the time had a conundrum. What did they do? But they did the unthinkable. They listened to their people and they actually cut spending and left major tax hikes on the cutting room floor.

Here's what that's done -- unemployment benefits cut by nearly half. Federal workforce was reduced by 14 percent. And the nation handed over their railway and air systems to private companies. I know it is all pretty radical. All in all the ratio of spending cuts to tax hikes, 7-1. And the results say it all. By 1998, Canada had -- Canada that is had gone from a nearly $37 billion deficit to a $3 billion surplus. The growth continues today.

Last year, their economy grew at a rate of more than three percent and hey, we didn't even get close to that -- unemployment closer to seven percent last month. We're still above nine percent. The facts seem pretty crystal clear. Cut and dry. Spending cuts saved their economy and it would do the same here. But President Obama and his fellow liberals refuse to face reality. They're having daily meetings on the debt, but refuse to address cuts in health care, rail projects and the ever popular green jobs not to mention the politically unpopular entitlement programs.

If you want a slap in the face here is a quote from the new book "The Canadian Century". Quote, "If we want to see what would become of Canada had we not lived through the difficult changes we need to look no further than Washington, D.C." Look, I can't believe I'm going to say this. Don't blame Canada. We have to emulate them.

What do you think about this? Does Canada have it right? Are we going about it all wrong? Here is what some of you are tweeting me @GerriWillisFBN. This person would rather live in the U.S. "Not even close for me. I don't want to pay high taxes to take care of my neighbor who doesn't take care of himself."

But Bob says "The U.S. for now, if Obama wins in 2012, Canada for sure." Here is your chance to weigh in on this, our poll question tonight. Would you rather live in the U.S. or Canada? You've got to tell us what you think here. Log on to GerriWillis.com.

Take the poll on the right-hand side of the screen and I will share the results at the end of tonight's show. And like me on Facebook. I had some interesting conversations with some of you there today and it is great to hear what you have to say, always love hearing from you. And of course you can write me an e-mail WillisReport@FoxBusiness.com

ANNOUNCER: Coming up on THE WILLIS REPORT, as the deadline for default gets closer and closer, is it time to get behind the "gang of six" plan? We'll ask our "Thursday Talkers" next.

Jobless claims are on the rise again. Our experts analyze America's economic crisis and if high unemployment is something we're going to have to just get used to.

Kids playing playhouse in six-figure flats while homeownership is on the decline, these rich youngsters are kicking back in posh cribs. Our "Watchdogs" bark about it. We're on the case next on THE WILLIS REPORT.

WILLIS: The White House today saying the economy vastly improved since President Obama took office. Let's see under eight percent unemployment rate (INAUDIBLE) to 9.2 percent today, what kind of voodoo economics is this administration playing with? Our "Thursday Talkers" Joe Trippi and Fred Barnes, they're here next.

WILLIS: Stories tonight that are making news tomorrow. Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood says the government will lose about $200 million a week in airline taxes and 4,000 workers will be furloughed if the Federal Aviation Administration is forced to shut down. LaHood also warns $2.5 billion in construction projects would be halted.

A shutdown looks increasingly likely because Congress hasn't been able to come to an agreement on legislation to extend the FAA's operating authority by midnight tomorrow. ISH (ph), an energy research group, says if the U.S. increased drilling activity in the Gulf of Mexico it would create nearly a quarter of a million jobs and add $44 billion to the economy next year.

The U.S. would also produce more tax revenue and more than 400,000 barrels of oil more per day. They say regulations in the wake of the Gulf oil spill have slowed down company profits. And Google cuddling up to D.C. -- no surprise there -- the tech giant spent more than $2 million on lobbying last quarter, surpassing the milestone for the first time. The 54 percent increase came and government scrutiny into Google's business practices. In another first, Google is now spending more on lobbying than Microsoft -- surprise there.

President Obama claims America is on his side in the debt debate.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA (D-IL), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You have 80 percent of the American people who support a balanced approach. Eighty percent of the American people support an approach that includes revenues, it includes cuts.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: All right, he's right on the numbers. A Gallup poll shows the vast majority of folks want at least some tax increases. But there are an awful lot of ways to cut the numbers on a very complicated issue.

So here's a simpler question with a simpler number. The president's latest approval rating -- hey, it's under 47 percent. He's been below 50 percent for a year-and-a-half. Can you still say America is on your side?

Let's turn to the "Thursday Talkers." Fred Barnes is the executive editor of The Weekly Standard and Joe Trippi is a Democratic strategist. Welcome to you both.

JOE TRIPPI, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST, FOX CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be with you.

FRED BARNES, WEEKLY STANDARD, FOX CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you.

WILLIS: All right, I want to start with "cut, cap and balance" because that seems to be the thing everybody's talking about. Democrats have taken a hard line against this legislation. The president says he'll veto it. Senator Conrad described its chances on the Senate floor today. Here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KENT CONRAD (D), NORTH DAKOTA: This legislation that has come over from the House cannot be the answer. It is not bipartisan, it is superpartisan. It is totally done on one side of the ledger. And Mr. President, it will not pass, it will not become law, and it should not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: Well, I think a lot of people agree it's DOA. Fred, to you. Is the ball out of the Republicans' court, or should they make other proposals now?

BARNES: Well, they're going to have to. It won't pass the Senate, and so they'll come to something else. Gerri, we're going to be hearing a fresh proposal practically every hour over the next few days, and something's going to wind up passing, and it may be a short-term thing while they're still negotiating.

And you know, the press reports have been not believable, to tell you the truth, the idea that they're still going to have a huge, grand bargain, which I think is not possible, that the "gang of six" thing is really catching on all over Washington, and it has no chance of passing the House.

So we're at square one. But at the end of the day, the ceiling on the debt limit is going to be increased. We're not going to have a default or bar the president from borrowing any more.

WILLIS: All right, Joe, are you as downbeat about the possibility for, say, a grand bargain or some other kind of solution that people get on board and get on board quickly?

TRIPPI: No, I think Fred's exactly right here.

WILLIS: Yes?

TRIPPI: I mean, we have an abundance of agreement. There's going to be -- there's going to be some agreement. They're not going to -- they're not going to default on anything. It's going to happen. What it is, I don't know because I agree with Fred, we're going to see something every hour here coming by.

And this thing is just dead on arrival from the House going over to the Senate. The Senate's not going to vote for it. The president's going to veto it. There will be something, but I don't think anybody can put their finger on what exactly that's going to be right now.

WILLIS: Let's talk about the "gang of six" proposal for just a second, and we'll look at some of the details. It would immediately cut $500 billion from the deficit. It would compel the Senate to make $3.7 trillion in cuts over 10 years. They've got to go and find those cuts. It would add a trillion in revenue, net tax relief of $1.5 trillion.

Fred, to you. You know, you said you didn't think that's going to go anywhere...

BARNES: Yes...

WILLIS: ... but could some elements of it survive?

BARNES: I don't believe -- look, the one thing that will survive from the "gang of six" is kicking the can down the road on entitlements and tax reform. Those are not going to get in any agreement now. And they'll -- and we can have something involving the president and Republicans. It'll say, We'll get to those things later, and here's a timetable for doing it in Congress. That's the most that's going to come out of the "gang of six" thing.

And look, the idea that it's a net tax cut -- it's a huge tax increase. Republicans have looked at it, and it's just not going to happen.

TRIPPI: You're not going to get a tax increase. Freshman in the House are not going to let that happen, and Boehner would have problems if he did, so that's going to be a problem there. And then spending -- any touching of entitlements is going to be a problem on the Democratic side in the House and the Senate.

So I think a grand bargain may be possible, but it would take some sort of quick-fix thing that does kick the can down long enough to figure it out. And the only -- you know, this new report that Boehner and the president are working on a $3 trillion cut, spending cut, with no tax increases sounds to me like something Boehner would definitely want.

BARNES: It does.

WILLIS: Right.

TRIPPI: It gets conservatives off of his back. I mean, the Tea Party people, gets the tax increase off, but I don't know how the president gets that done. We'll see (INAUDIBLE)

BARNES: There has to be something -- there has to be something in there for Democrats and for president Obama, you know, because they both have to go along with this. You know, look, the hardest thing to find, Gerri, is an agreement that both the Senate and the House can pass.

WILLIS: But Fred, they want...

BARNES: They haven't found that yet.

WILLIS: They want opposite things. I mean, how do you find...

BARNES: Well, that's why it's...

WILLIS: ... common ground when one side says raise taxes, and the other side says don't raise taxes?

BARNES: Well...

(CROSSTALK)

BARNES: You might have to raise taxes...

TRIPPI: Two trains coming right at each other (INAUDIBLE)

WILLIS: Listen, one quick follow-up question, and I'm going to give it to you, Joe. President Obama -- I said in the intro here that his approval rating is falling. Does he have the standing to put forward -- to see through what he wants to have done?

TRIPPI: Well, that's actually the fascinating thing about this because he's not wrong about that. I'm not talking about his approval ratings, but it's clear and a lot of recent polling says that the American people are starting to blame Republicans more than him for not coming to an agreement. I'm not saying he's going to -- we'll have to see what the agreement is to see if that carries forward, but right now, they're blaming the Republicans more than the president.

WILLIS: Well, that's our last word there. Sorry about that, Fred. You've got to come back to talk more. Appreciate your time.

BARNES: All right.

WILLIS: Both of you today, great job. Thank you.

All right, still ahead: Remember those treehouses you used to build as a child? Now kids these days are playing in replica mansions that sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars. You're going to want to see this. The "Willis Watchdogs" bark about it next.

WILLIS: A local TV station in Florida has been reporting the state has been selling personal information to private investigators for years, raking in almost $63 million. Now, the information comes from drivers' licenses, including numbers and birth dates. It's sold for 1 cent per file, and it adds up quickly.

Time to let the "Willis Watchdogs" out. George Jarkesy is the chairman and manager -- managing member, that is, of the National Eagles and Angels Association in Austin, Texas. Ben Ferguson is a radio talk show host in Memphis. And Susan Solovic is the CEO and co-founder of Itsyourbiz.com.

Susan, let's start with you.

SUSAN SOLOVIC, ITSYOURBIZ.COM CEO AND CO-FOUNDER: OK. Well, actually, here's what I have to say about this situation. It's public documentation. It's been available everywhere for many years. When I practiced law, I had access to it. So many professionals have had access to that information.

But I have to applaud the state of Florida because everybody's got a budget crisis right now, applaud them for figuring out a creative way to raise some money. And a lot of states right now, because of the housing crisis, are, you know, losing revenue base with their property taxes. So what are they doing? They're slapping small businesses with more taxes.

But Florida is ranked 18th in the most entrepreneurial-friendly state. So good for them.

WILLIS: All right...

SOLOVIC: They're figuring out a way to fund their budget.

WILLIS: But Ben, my information -- if you can sell my information, give me the money, you know what I mean?

BEN FERGUSON, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: Look, I'm worth more than a penny, my information on my driver's license, for goodness sake! I mean, if you're going to -- if you're going to whore out my information, at least get a dime for it or a nickel, for goodness sakes! I don't call that good entrepreneurship. I think they need to go for some more cash, or at least let me have the option to give you one penny so you don't sell my information. Give me 5 cents! I guarantee you, people would go and pay 5 cents to not have you sell their information!

WILLIS: That's a good point.

FERGUSON: I just think this is a bad idea!

WILLIS: All right, George, so is it innovative on the part of the state, or are they actually just, you know, ripping us off?

GEORGE JARKESY, NATIONAL EAGLES AND ANGELS ASSOC. CHAIRMAN: Look, it's innovative. And if you look at it, that's $60 million that the taxpayers didn't have to come up with. Not only do I agree with it, all of that information that you have and that they're selling is available on the Internet. I know people that think that they have private data on the Internet or that they're not listed, but if you want the data, you can find it.

It's innovative. And not only that, other states should try to do that and make money for their state.

WILLIS: Boy, oh, boy, you people would sell anything!

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: All right, the Federal Election Commission says John Edwards -- John Edwards needs to repay the U.S. Treasury more than $2 million. The FEC said his 2008 presidential campaign understated its cash and overstated its expenses. The campaign got nearly $13 million in federal matching funds.

Ben, want to have a little fun with this story?

FERGUSON: Yes. John Edwards should have learned to spend more of his own campaign money real quick (INAUDIBLE) '08. No, he was already doing that, paying women to not talk about his love child! So I think he maxed out his money. I think he just screwed up, and it's time to pay back the taxpayers. And you know what? He is a lawyer. I think this could take a while until we get our money back.

WILLIS: George, what do you say?

JARKESY: Well, it was a unanimous decision, and I think he should pay the money back, and not only pay the money back but pay it with interest. He owes our government. And if you or I owe the government, we pay them, and he should pay us, and pay us as quickly as possible.

WILLIS: Pay early, pay often, Susan.

SOLOVIC: Well, actually, you said John Edwards -- he's a lawyer -- He's a good trial lawyer. If he were on the other side, he'd be aggressively fighting this situation. And here's what I think. During his campaign, you know, he really wasn't thinking with his head, he was thinking with another part of his anatomy. He took it...

(CROSSTALK)

WILLIS: ... going to say what that was!

SOLOVIC: (INAUDIBLE) not to get that technical, but he got the eye off the ball (INAUDIBLE)

(LAUGHTER)

SOLOVIC: He needs to pay the money back. It's that simple.

WILLIS: All right. OK. I think we'll move on.

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: You get the picture, right? All right, The New York Times is reporting on a new status symbol among some parents, some really, really wealthy parents, posh playhouses. Reportedly, some of these parents are spending upwards of $200,000 on high-end replica mansions for their kids to play in. And many of the companies that produce these make-believe palaces say their profits are booming, despite the fact that we're still in recession. George, what do you say?

JARKESY: Well, I read the article there today in "The New York Times," and you know, the gentleman that they were talking about there runs a big company. He's built a company. He's made a lot of money for his investors. If that's how he wants to spend the money of his princess (ph), then that's great.

But you know, what people really need to think about is how many jobs were generated by that expenditure. So I'm for it.

WILLIS: Well, Ben, I mean, you know, good on you if you can start a business to do that. But I mean, my mother would have said, You know, there are kids starving out there. What are you doing spending $200,000 on a playhouse?

FERGUSON: Yes, I'm going to make -- I'm going to make a -- I'm going to make a prediction. There's going to be some back property taxes on this poor little girl one day.

(LAUGHTER)

FERGUSON: Barack Obama's now going to be calling out these people with playhouses. And oh, by the way, the tax -- the guy's flying those private jets. So I'm telling you, I wouldn't have done the article because somebody's going to want some money off this! At the same time, look, it's his little daughter. He's got the cash. He wants to spend it. More power to him, you know?

WILLIS: All right. OK. Well, Susan, I'm sorry, we've got to go.

SOLOVIC: OK.

WILLIS: We're out of time. You've got to come back.

SOLOVIC: I'll be back.

WILLIS: All right, George, Ben, Susan, thank you so much. Great job.

And up next, more on today's the Dodd-Frank anniversary. How is the new law impacting your wallet and your credit score. John Ulzheimer -- he's coming in. He's going to tell us next.

WILLIS: As part of the Dodd-Frank bill we've been talking about, the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau officially opens today, and they're rolling out new rules intended to give consumers better insight into their own credit situation. And that includes sending you a copy of your credit score any time you're denied credit. But not all credit scores are alike, and there are things you need to be aware of.

John Ulzheimer is the president of consumer education at Smartcredit.com. John, great to see you again.

JOHN ULZHEIMER, SMARTCREDIT.COM CONSUMER ED. PRES.: Thank you for having me, Gerri. I appreciate it.

WILLIS: Well, you know, look, the credit score is the big kahuna for consumers. It is the number. It's the thing you've got to have. You used to have to pay for it. Now it's free. I've got to say, that's a good thing from Dodd-Frank.

ULZHEIMER: It's absolutely a good thing. Look, this is a very, very complicated provision of Dodd-Frank that's going to get a heck of a workout right out of the gate. Over a half a billion -- with a B -- half a billion credit applications are either denied or adversely approved, meaning approved but with less advantageous terms, every single year.

And every single one of those that's based on a credit score from this point going forward is going to require or trigger a notice from the lender, a letter to the consumer that tells them they've been denied based on the score. And they're going to have to include the score with that letter.

WILLIS: All right, so when am I due that? When, where are people going to say, OK, Gerri, you can have that credit score?

ULZHEIMER: You can have it if you're denied credit based on the score, if you're approved but with poor terms based on a credit score, if you have an APR on a credit card go up because of your credit score, or -- and this is important, this one has kind of flown under the radar -- if your insurance premiums go up or if your utility provider requires a deposit. If they're using a legitimate credit score, per the definition of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, then a credit score is required there, as well.

WILLIS: All right. I want to remind people how these things get used. It determines whether you get a mortgage loan, car loan, determines the rate on you credit cards, cell phones, insurance, utilities -- I mean, anytime you go out and buy something, right?

ULZHEIMER: Everything. Oh, yes.

WILLIS: They're looking at your credit score right over your shoulder.

ULZHEIMER: Other than applying for a job, your credit score is used almost across the board for almost every other transaction that you execute with a lender.

WILLIS: All right, now, here's the crazy thing that you want to talk about which I think is critical and surprising. You say that credit scores sold to consumers are different from the ones that companies may use. How so?

ULZHEIMER: Yes. And this is one of those things that people kind of in the know in the credit world already knew this. But the CFPB released a study earlier this week that kind of quantified what a lot of people already knew, which is that the scores that are being marketed aggressively to consumers on television ads, on the Internet, over the radio, at sporting events -- they're not really the same scores that are being sold to the lenders, which is problematic for a couple reasons.

First off, consumers are actually spending money on these things. They're not being given to them for free. They have to sign up for trial subscription services, then are being billed for them. So they're not getting the ROI out of their investment.

Second is, is the score in some cases could be misleading the consumer to believe that they're either a poorer credit risk than they really are or actually a better credit risk than they really are. And they walk into a lender's office with unrealistic expectations of how they're going to get treated, which is problematic because it can lead to significant embarrassment on the consumer's part.

WILLIS: But is that because we're just not educated about them, or is that because they're trying to mislead us?

ULZHEIMER: No, I don't think that they're purposely trying to mislead anybody. But let me give you a great example. Let's say that Gerri Willis's legitimate FICO score is 750, but the score that she gets on some Web site somewhere is 698. A 698 is very different than a 750, yet if you walk into a lender, you're going to expect to be treated like a 698, which is very different than how you're going to get treated because of your 750. That can cut both ways.

That's the biggest issue in some people's mind with respect to these artificial or educational credit scores that are being so aggressively marketed to consumers.

WILLIS: And, oh, by the way, it's 806, my friend, not 750. But I'll let you slide on that.

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: Let's show folks...

ULZHEIMER: I had to be kind.

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: There are a million companies out there that do this, and we all know Equifax, Experian, Transunion. You'll also see Affinion, Intersections, Vertrue and Fico. So at the end of the day, this is a private sector business, OK? I know you think you have to rely on this like you rely on information coming from the federal government, but the reality is, these are private companies selling your personal information, and it may be true, it may not be true.

ULZHEIMER: Yes. I think the takeaway from this is buyer beware. Buyer beware. If you find text on these Web sites that say these are educational scores, these may not be the scores that lenders are actually using, then you have to decide whether or not you want to cough up $14.95 a month to monitor your credit report and see that score all the time.

Conversely, if you want to, there are a lot of Web sites that will actually give you scores for free. They may or may not be the same ones your lenders are using, but they're out there. Credit Karma, Credit Sesame...

WILLIS: Right.

ULZHEIMER: ... Credit.com does it. So go there and get them for free, and at least you haven't given someone your credit card. And the expectation is, Look, I know this isn't my real score, but hey, I didn't pay for it.

WILLIS: Well, very good advice. Great to see you, John. Thanks for coming back in. Appreciate it.

ULZHEIMER: You bet, Gerri.

WILLIS: All right. We'll be right back with my "2 Cents More" and the results of our poll.

WILLIS: Earlier this hour, we told you how Canada got it right. When it slipped into its debt crisis it was spending cuts, not tax hikes that got the country back on track. So we asked on Gerriwillis.com, Would you rather live in the U.S. or in Canada? Sixty-five percent said the U.S. Yay! Thirty-five percent said Canada. Be sure to log onto Gerriwillis.com for our on-line question every weekday.

And finally tonight, remember Angelo Mozilo from Countrywide? His company was at the heart of the mortgage meltdown. Regulators eventually came in and forced Mozilo himself to pony up $67.5 million, and that was the biggest settlement of its kind at the time. But criminal charges were never made against the executive who was at the cutting edge of some of the most questionable mortgage industry practices.

Now the company finally paying $108 million to settle charges it charged excessive fees to consumers. The Federal Trade Commission brought the charge and the company agreed to pay a year ago, but Countrywide is just now beginning to pony up the money. Some 450,000 customers, a record- size group, will get about 240 bucks each, if you do the math. Cold comfort if you lost your home because of these practices. And that's my "2 Cents More."

That's it for tonight's "Willis Report." During the past hour, the national debt has increased to $14.522 trillion, and your share now nearly $130,000.

Thanks for joining us. And don't forget to DVR the show if you can't catch us live. We'll see you right back here tomorrow night.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V7X-XFH1-DYHJ-34MY-00000-00Will new Congress rein in tech?2019-01-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. D,1,1Will new Congress rein in tech?By Hiawatha BrayGlobe StaffABSTRACT

Divided over many issues, Republicans and Democrats appear to be slowly coalescing around a few big ideas to regulate big technology companies.

BODY

Not too many years ago, hardly anybody in Washington wanted to regulate the Internet. Suddenly, almost everybody does — or claims to.

For decades, Internet companies were sheltered by a bipartisan consensus: Regulate with a light touch, and see what happens.

The results have been extraordinary. Facebook and Google are now among the world's biggest companies. However, their actions also have subjected millions of users to the threat of identity theft and loss of privacy, and record fines by the US government for privacy-related violations.

And now members of both parties are in a regulating frame of mind, according to lawmakers and industry-watchers alike. Some lawmakers are calling for more aggressive antitrust enforcement against Big Tech. There's even talk of reviving the idea of Net neutrality, which requires that Internet service providers treat all data alike.

But the idea that appears to have the best chance of success, these people say, is a law setting national standards for online privacy and data security.

Witness the similarity between a Massachusetts Democrat and a Tennessee Republican.

"I think the American people now realize they deserve a privacy bill of rights," said US Senator Edward Markey of Massachusetts. "The day of reckoning has arrived for the Internet industry."

And from Senator Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee:

"I agree with consumers who demand their privacy be protected in an Internet ecosystem where everybody is playing by the same set of rules," she said in a statement to the Globe.

Another Republican senator, John Kennedy of Louisiana, proposed a privacy bill last year, in tandem with Democratic colleague Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota. Kennedy told the Globe he plans to reintroduce the bill in the current session.

Even the tech industry's biggest companies — Facebook, Google, Microsoft and Apple — have come out in favor of a federal privacy and data security law. And in mid-January, the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation (ITIF), a think tank funded in part by Big Tech, called for a "grand bargain" that would repeal all existing federal laws covering the privacy and security of various medical and financial data, and replace this patchwork with a single statute that covers personal data in all its forms.

But don't expect lawmakers to start crowing that they've finally brought Big Tech to heel.

Ernesto Falcon, legislative counsel for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, an online civil liberties group, said the tech industry is getting on board because they fear tough privacy laws being enacted by the states, especially California. They prefer a single nationwide privacy standard—and one that's as toothless as possible.

"The idea would be to have a very weak federal law," said Falcon. "That's an absurd proposition, and they'll have to walk away from that if they ­actually want legislation."

For instance, the proposed "grand bargain" from the ITIF would prohibit individuals from suing for privacy violations or data security breaches. And it doesn't include data minimization, the principle that companies may collect only the personal data they need to deliver specific services. ­Data minimization would block apps from tracking your location when you're not using them. That would eliminate fat revenue streams for app makers that track you constantly and resell the data to marketing companies.

ITIF vice president Daniel Castro said companies use the vast amounts of data they ­collect to devise new services for consumers; force them to collect less data, and you can expect less innovation.

"There are lots of things you can do that protect consumer privacy but that's bad for ­innovation," Castro said.

Instead, the ITIF wants lawmakers to give companies wide latitude in what data, and how much of it, they can collect, while giving consumers the option to opt out if they choose.

ITIF's grand bargain would also include "preemption," a feature that would overrule all state privacy laws. The federal law would become the national standard, making it easier and cheaper for companies to comply. "Then you don't have the problem of companies having to fight a lot of lawsuits in different states," Castro said.

But the tech companies could use their clout in Washington to enact a federal law with few meaningful limits on their access to our data.

"My fear is that the companies are going to arrive and try to get the lowest common denominator," said Markey. "We need a federal privacy law that sets strong mandatory, not voluntary, standards. Then we can talk about preemption."

Democrat Ro Khanna, a congressman who represents Silicon Valley, has drawn up an "Internet Bill of Rights" full of limitations on Internet companies, such as data minimization, and a mandate that companies get permission before sharing customer data with any other person or organization.

At least there's general agreement that some kind of privacy and security protections are needed. But on other tech-law issues, consensus is harder to come by.

Net neutrality, for instance — the principle that all network traffic should be treated exactly alike.

The Federal Communications Commission under President Obama adopted Net neutrality rules that in principle would let the agency enforce equality among network traffic as well as the prices charged by Internet carriers, and their quality of service. The Trump administration moved swiftly to undo that approach.

Both Democrats and Republicans have said they would back a Net neutrality law. But Khanna, for example, wants a law based on the broader standard in place under Obama; Republicans such as Blackburn prefer a simpler, stand-alone law that would simply mandate Net neutrality, and do nothing else. Don't expect much progress here.

Khanna is also calling for a law to mandate "data portability," requiring Facebook and other social networks to move a user's data to another host on request, just as a cellphone user can switch his phone number from one carrier to another.

Facebook has no serious competition today, but Khanna believes that with data portability, it would be far easier for smaller players to offer ­consumers an alternative.

"You make it the law," said Khanna. "You have to allow people to move their data, just like they can move their phone number."

But data portability is a hugely complex issue, and raises privacy threats of its own. For example, do you have the right to port information about your Facebook friends to a different network without their permission? Until such questions are answered, data portability seems like a nonstarter.

And there's the simmering question of whether the federal government should use antitrust law to rein in giants like Facebook and Google, or even break them up, as Standard Oil was dismantled in the early 20th century.

Many economists argue that existing antitrust law doesn't apply to Google and Facebook because they don't charge for their products and therefore don't obviously create direct financial harm to consumers.

Democratic US Representative David Cicilline of Rhode Island plans an antitrust bill specifically targeting Big Tech. It's might have a fighting chance, as quite a few Republicans have also been making antitrust noises of late. During the recent confirmation hearings for Attorney General-designate William Barr, Senators Josh Hawley of Missouri and Mike Lee of Utah both demanded tougher antitrust enforcement from the Justice Department.

Whatever the fate of these legislative proposals, you can expect them to keep coming. The era of "light touch" ­Internet regulation is probably over.

Hiawatha Bray can be reached at hiawatha.bray@globe.com Follow him on Twitter @GlobeTechLab.

urn:contentItem:6043-M7T1-JCMN-Y03B-00000-00Will New Retail Stores Boost Amazon Stock?2020-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:24ZLexisNexisWill New Retail Stores Boost Amazon Stock?247sarah

Jun 12, 2020( 24/7 Wall St.: http://www.247wallst.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Services Will New Retail Stores Boost Amazon Stock? Carl Sullivan[1] June 12, 2020 8:38 am While the coronavirus-related shutdowns did wonders for Amazon.com Inc.'s (NASDAQ: AMZN[2]) e-commerce delivery business, the online retailing giant hasn't entirely abandoned the physical store format. In fact, the Seattle-based company is building out a new brick-and-mortar brand right now, even as America's retailers dig out from the COVID-19 pandemic. The move is a sign of Amazon's dominance and innovation in retail sales.

Even as local businesses are suffering, Amazon is confident there's still a place for physical retail.And the stores offer Amazon another opportunity to market its digital devices, such as the Kindle. These retail stores are a tiny part of Amazon's overall business, but may offer important branding value over time.Overall, analysts have nothing but love[3] for Amazon lately. Many have boosted their price targets for the stock to over $3,000.Along with the overall market, Amazon dropped substantially Thursday. The stock closed at $2,557.96, down 3.4%. Investors were reacting to worrying signs about coronavirus cases and the broader economy. There was also late breaking news about an antitrust case against Amazon in Europe. Namesake Store Called Amazon 4-star, the new retail outlets have already opened in some cities while others are being built. Right now, stores are open in Colorado and Texas. Other locations, including New York City and Seattle, are closed temporarily due to the coronavirus.The company has announced plans for 30 locations in 17 states. Coming soon are stores in Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Maryland, New Jersey and North Carolina. Even the famed Mall of America in Bloomington, Minnesota, will be getting a 4-star.As the name implies, the stores carry mostly products that have been reviewed four stars and above by Amazon's online customers. Store curators may include some items with lower ratings and new trending items.The stores will carry a limited selection of items sold on Amazon.com, including consumer electronics, toys, games, books, home items and more. Amazon sees 4-star as an extension of Amazon.com, and will mimic some popular online features such as 'Most Wished-For' merchandise and 'If You Like, Then You'll Love' sections.'Our team of curators looks at pre-orders, sales trends, customer reviews and ratings, customer wish lists, and what amazon.com editorial teams have curated online to select only the most-loved amazon.com products for our store,' the company said on its website.Amazon Prime members who visit 4-star shops will get special discounted prices, which will be displayed alongside the normal retail price. Amazon will use the stores to try to upsell Prime memberships, which will be offered in free 30-day trials in the stores.Amazon 4-star locations will also offer an opportunity for consumers to try out Amazon devices. Customers can test drive the Echo, Kindle, Fire TV and Fire Tablet. And Amazon employees will be on hand to answer questions, the company said.This isn't Amazon's first go at in-store sales of its own devices. After Amazon purchased the Whole Foods grocery store chain, it displayed and sold Alexa speakers alongside fresh produce and other staples.Amazon 4-star shouldn't be confused with Amazon Go or Amazon Books, which are separate retail stores. There are currently plans for 24 Amazon Books stores. Amazon Go, which sells food, has locations in New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Seattle. Many of these are also temporarily closed.Amazon Go is the sophisticated prototype grocery store that the company is testing. Instead of using cash registers, high-tech scanners charge consumers for each item they remove from store shelves. They simply walk out when they've completed their shopping list. The technology could impact the entire future of in-person shopping.The company also has a handful of Amazon Pop Up stores that feature a 'try-before-you-buy' experience for products like AmazonBasics Bedding. Analyst Love Earlier this week, RBC Capital Markets boosted its price target to $3,300, the highest target currently set for Amazon. The average target sits at $2,623.53.Besides RBC, other analysts also boosted their targets this week: Jefferies Financial Group ($3,100), Bank of America ($3,000) and Robert W. Baird ($2,750).Amazon has a whopping 44 Buy recommendations, three Holds and one Sell. Wells Fargo & Co. and the Royal Bank of Canada reiterated their Buy ratings this week.In revising its price target, RBC Capital said its recent survey of online shopping behavior shows that 'Amazon is likely the best global play off of online retail.' Consumers surveyed by RBC said they were shopping more at Amazon.com.The survey also found more shoppers have become Prime members: 67% said they were Prime members, compared with 59% in 2019.Overall, RBC predicts that the COVID-19 shift to online shopping has permanently altered consumer behavior. The firm found that other online retailers, such as Walmart, eBay and Etsy are also doing very well in this environment.To meet the increased demand, Amazon hired 175,000 temporary workers this spring. Many of those roles are being converted to permanent status. By April, the company had over 935,000 employees. That's a lot, but Walmart employs more, 2.2 million worldwide and 1.5 million in the U.S. 24/7 Wall St. Is Antitrust Push a Real Threat to Facebook Stock? https://247wallst.com/media/2020/06/11/is-antitrust-a-real-threat-to-facebook-stock/ Antitrust Case In a rare bit of negative news for Jeff Bezos' company, The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday that an antitrust lawsuit is imminent.The newspaper said European Union officials are preparing to charge Amazon with abusing its power to squash smaller rivals. The action is expected in the next couple of weeks.Regulators are focused on the allegation that Amazon scoops up data from third-party sellers and uses that info to undercut them. An earlier Journal investigation, based on interviews with former Amazon employees, said the company sometimes used data on third-party sellers to develop its own rival products.Amazon didn't comment on the Journal report, but in the past has denied violating any antitrust laws.The EU case against Amazon is just the latest of many antitrust investigations[4] on both sides of the Atlantic against big tech companies, including Google, Facebook and Apple. European regulators have been more aggressive, and their case against Amazon could be one of their biggest.Last year, the EU fined Google 1.7 billion Euros[5] for abusing its power in the online advertising market. It was the third huge fine the Union levied on the search giant. Subscribe to Our Newsletter Read more: Services[6], AMZN[7], Corporate Performance[8] [ 1]:   https://247wallst.com/author/carl-sullivan/ [ 2]:   https://247wallst.com/companies/amzn/ [ 3]:   https://247wallst.com/services/2020/06/10/analysts-vs-critics-on-amazon-stock/ [ 4]:   https://247wallst.com/media/2020/06/11/is-antitrust-a-real-threat-to-facebook-stock/ [ 5]:   https://247wallst.com/technology-3/2019/03/20/will-a-1-7-billion-fine-make-google-flinch/ [ 6]:   https://247wallst.com/./services/ [ 7]:   https://247wallst.com/companies/amzn/ [ 8]:   https://247wallst.com/topics/corporate-performance/

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YH4-PBP1-JBG3-63CT-00000-00Will Our Most Important Industry Survive the Coronavirus?2020-03-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:24ZLexisNexisOPINIONWill Our Most Important Industry Survive the Coronavirus?Kara Swisher

Governments need Big Tech now more than ever.

Governments need Big Tech now more than ever.

Last month, as the coronavirus started to spread here in the United States, I wrote about a smallish online conferencing company, Zoom Video Communications, saying thatwe might want to pay attention to itbecause it makes working from home easier. Well, with the escalating crisis, Zoom is now worth more than four airlines combined — United, Delta, American and JetBlue — with a market cap of just above $44 billion.

With all due respect to Zoom, which makes a very good product that is very useful, sometimes problematic (do a search for “ZoomBombing”) and even delightful (there has been a Zoom wedding): That’s just insane.

How crazy? Well, along with its huge valuation, Zoom has seen its share price go from $62 about a year ago when it went public to close to $160 today. The company has an unheard-of price-to-earning ratio of 1,865 (this is usually considered a good measure of a company’s true value; by way of comparison, Facebook’s is 23 and Google’s is 21).

This is Wall Street over-indexing to very dire problems — so it’s a good time to assess how the coronavirus crisis will actually affect big tech. How will the most important industry in the United States emerge from a financial slump? How will government efforts to alleviate the pain of the crash affect the industry? Given tech’s outsized role in both the stock market and the larger economy, how the industry fares will be important to the overall recovery.

Let’s start on a positive note: Despite having lost big chunks of market value since the beginning of the year, nearly every company among the big five (Microsoft, Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, Facebook) will do just fine when this crisis eventually passes.

That’s because all are larded up with cash, and some have a nearly monopolistic grip on their business arenas, such as online advertising (Google), e-commerce (Amazon) and social media (Facebook), that are not going away. That is a head start that lesser rivals — who will now have to eat up their seed corn to stay viable — cannot compete against.

There will be a culling of most competitors of these giants that will only strengthen the power and reach of the behemoths, eliminating pesky roadblocks to their further domination. This is obviously not a good thing in the long run.

As the economy returns to normal, the impulse will be toward bolstering our big corporations in hopes they will repair the unemployment problem. And those companies that are able to hire and protect their employees will be the most feted, and their success will be one of the key benchmarks of the economy’s health.

Its main ad business will no doubt take a hit over the next few quarters, but Facebook is reporting a jump in video views, messaging and news consumption, as users try to connect online while sheltering in place. To generate good will, Facebook has been handing out extra pay to its employees, while also donating face masks it had bought last year for the California wildfires.

Alphabet’s Google search service and YouTube video unit — also subject to the vicissitudes of the advertising market — have seen surges in use, while many of the company’s other products and its cloud services are doing well. And that trend will persist: More Americans are using these services more intensely and becoming accustomed to their efficacy.

Amazon will be one of the main beneficiaries of the crisis as more consumers use its delivery and entertainment services, and as more companies move over to its cloud business, Amazon Web Services. So too for its analog Whole Foods Market, which has remained open during the slowdown for both delivery and walk-in customers. Amazon said last week it was looking to hire 100,000 warehouse workers to meet the increased demand, which is no surprise.

And so it goes: Apple’s supply chain from China is being restored as that country recovers ahead of the rest of the world from Covid-19, and its diversification into other services like streaming has only been bolstered by the crisis. Microsoft’s cloud service and Teams collaboration product have also experienced a spike in use.

And one major plus for all of them: Their questionable behaviors around competition, the spread of disinformation and hate speech, addiction and more will not be subject to the same regulatory scrutiny that had been building over the last year. In fact, it seems less likely that government officials — in the United States, at least, where their hands are full with more pressing issues — will be as enthusiastic to pass legislation or levy fines to thwart the growing power of tech.

Still, some big tech companies are vulnerable. Airbnb, the home-rental giant that has seen its listings drop precipitously, will likely not go public this year as planned. The company will probably need to raise more funds at less attractive terms to add to its $4 billion in liquidity, and need to do yeoman’s work to re-convince its hosts and customers that high-analog-touch businesses are OK (side note: Their hotel rivals are even more exposed).

The same is true for the car-sharing leader, Uber, which was already struggling with increased costs as states seek to recategorizetheir drivers from contract workers to employees entitled to benefits. And getting people back into the habit of using Uber cars instead of their own after the pandemic ends will be a heavy lift.

As for the scooter and other alternate mobility businesses that Uber has been building, along with competitors like Lime and Bird, it’s going to be a bumpy ride. The only saving grace is that the onset of warmer weather could mean increased usage.

But there’s one major thing that tech companies cannot avoid: taxes. As the well-known Silicon Valley investor Chamath Palihapitiya pointed out to me in an interview this week, “It’s where the money is, so it is where governments are going to go when they need relief.” He added that a federal role in backing businesses will make it a bigger player in tech and beyond. “All U.S. citizens will all become shareholders in a way,” he said.

Governments are racking up ginormous deficits for stimulus packages, and they will have higher costs for health care — and as Mr. Palihapitiya noted, all of this has to be paid by someone. There is no question that governments will turn to businesses with huge profits to help foot the bill. That means big tech, more than any other industry, both here in the United States and abroad.

Because there are two things we can always rely on, during this horrible pandemic and in normal times: death and taxes.

The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some   tips. And here’s our email:   letters@nytimes.com.

Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook,   Twitter (@NYTopinion) and   Instagram, and sign up for the   Opinion Today newsletter.

PHOTO: As more consumers turn to online delivery and entertainment services, companies like Amazon will benefit. (PHOTOGRAPH BY Carlo Allegri/Reuters FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YHG-1H11-JC85-N18P-00000-00Will Our Most Important Industry Survive the Coronavirus?2020-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:25ZLexisNexisOPINIONWill Our Most Important Industry Survive the Coronavirus?Kara Swisher

Governments need Big Tech now more than ever.

Last month, as the coronavirus started to spread here in the United States, I wrote about a smallish online conferencing company, Zoom Video Communications, saying that we might want to pay attention to it because it makes working from home easier. Well, with the escalating crisis, Zoom is now worth more than four airlines combined - United, Delta, American and JetBlue - with a market cap of just above $44 billion.

With all due respect to Zoom, which makes a very good product that is very useful, sometimes problematic (do a search for "ZoomBombing") and even delightful (there has been a Zoom wedding): That's just insane.

How crazy? Well, along with its huge valuation, Zoom has seen its share price go from $62 about a year ago when it went public to close to $160 today. The company has an unheard-of price-to-earning ratio of 1,865 (this is usually considered a good measure of a company's true value; by way of comparison, Facebook's is 23 and Google's is 21).

This is Wall Street over-indexing to very dire problems - so it's a good time to assess how the coronavirus crisis will actually affect big tech. How will the most important industry in the United States emerge from a financial slump? How will government efforts to alleviate the pain of the crash affect the industry? Given tech's outsized role in both the stock market and the larger economy, how the industry fares will be important to the overall recovery.

Let's start on a positive note: Despite having lost big chunks of market value since the beginning of the year, nearly every company among the big five (Microsoft, Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, Facebook) will do just fine when this crisis eventually passes.

That's because all are larded up with cash, and some have a nearly monopolistic grip on their business arenas, such as online advertising (Google), e-commerce (Amazon) and social media (Facebook), that are not going away. That is a head start that lesser rivals - who will now have to eat up their seed corn to stay viable - cannot compete against.

There will be a culling of most competitors of these giants that will only strengthen the power and reach of the behemoths, eliminating pesky roadblocks to their further domination. This is obviously not a good thing in the long run.

As the economy returns to normal, the impulse will be toward bolstering our big corporations in hopes they will repair the unemployment problem. And those companies that are able to hire and protect their employees will be the most feted, and their success will be one of the key benchmarks of the economy's health.

Its main ad business will no doubt take a hit over the next few quarters, but Facebook is reporting a jump in video views, messaging and news consumption, as users try to connect online while sheltering in place. To generate good will, Facebook has been handing out extra pay to its employees, while also donating face masks it had bought last year for the California wildfires.

Alphabet's Google search service and YouTube video unit - also subject to the vicissitudes of the advertising market - have seen surges in use, while many of the company's other products and its cloud services are doing well. And that trend will persist: More Americans are using these services more intensely and becoming accustomed to their efficacy.

Amazon will be one of the main beneficiaries of the crisis as more consumers use its delivery and entertainment services, and as more companies move over to its cloud business, Amazon Web Services. So too for its analog Whole Foods Market, which has remained open during the slowdown for both delivery and walk-in customers. Amazon said last week it was looking to hire 100,000 warehouse workers to meet the increased demand, which is no surprise.

And so it goes: Apple's supply chain from China is being restored as that country recovers ahead of the rest of the world from Covid-19, and its diversification into other services like streaming has only been bolstered by the crisis. Microsoft's cloud service and Teams collaboration product have also experienced a spike in use.

And one major plus for all of them: Their questionable behaviors around competition, the spread of disinformation and hate speech, addiction and more will not be subject to the same regulatory scrutiny that had been building over the last year. In fact, it seems less likely that government officials - in the United States, at least, where their hands are full with more pressing issues - will be as enthusiastic to pass legislation or levy fines to thwart the growing power of tech.

Still, some big tech companies are vulnerable. Airbnb, the home-rental giant that has seen its listings drop precipitously, will likely not go public this year as planned. The company will probably need to raise more funds at less attractive terms to add to its $4 billion in liquidity, and need to do yeoman's work to re-convince its hosts and customers that high-analog-touch businesses are OK (side note: Their hotel rivals are even more exposed).

The same is true for the car-sharing leader, Uber, which was already struggling with increased costs as states seek to recategorize their drivers from contract workers to employees entitled to benefits. And getting people back into the habit of using Uber cars instead of their own after the pandemic ends will be a heavy lift.

As for the scooter and other alternate mobility businesses that Uber has been building, along with competitors like Lime and Bird, it's going to be a bumpy ride. The only saving grace is that the onset of warmer weather could mean increased usage.

But there's one major thing that tech companies cannot avoid: taxes. As the well-known Silicon Valley investor Chamath Palihapitiya pointed out to me in an interview this week, "It's where the money is, so it is where governments are going to go when they need relief." He added that a federal role in backing businesses will make it a bigger player in tech and beyond. "All U.S. citizens will all become shareholders in a way," he said.

Governments are racking up ginormous deficits for stimulus packages, and they will have higher costs for health care - and as Mr. Palihapitiya noted, all of this has to be paid by someone. There is no question that governments will turn to businesses with huge profits to help foot the bill. That means big tech, more than any other industry, both here in the United States and abroad.

Because there are two things we can always rely on, during this horrible pandemic and in normal times: death and taxes.

The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We'd like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here's our email: letters@nytimes.com.

Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook, Twitter (@NYTopinion) and Instagram, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.

urn:contentItem:5VFM-PK11-JCF2-H359-00000-00Will proposed EU legislation “stick the knife” into US tech giants?2019-02-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:25ZLexisNexisEGI NEWSWill proposed EU legislation “stick the knife” into US tech giants?James Clegg

Matt Reynolds, tech reporter for WiredIn the halls of the European Parliament’s Strasbourg building, a single word in an MEP’s ear is enough to stoke up feelings of European solidarity and anti-American hubris. GAFA – a term coined in the French press that quickly leaked out to wider European usage – is an easy shorthand for lobbyists and legislators who wish to conjure the spectre of American cultural imperialism.It stands for Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon, but barely underneath the surface is a sly criticism of big US tech firms that seek to sidestep regulation and leave Europe in their thrall.Trump cardOver the past two-and-a-half years the EU has been holding on to an anti-GAFA trump card – a sweeping update to online copyright. But while MEPs have clamoured to stick the knife into big tech, they are in danger of ushering in legislation that could end up solidifying the hegemony of exactly the same US firms they are so keen to curtail.The controversial bits of the proposed Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market – as far as the online giants are concerned – come down to two articles that its critics say will fundamentally change the way the internet works in Europe and stifle online innovation in the process. Article 13 – sometimes called the “meme ban” – would make online platforms (think YouTube, Twitter and Facebook) responsible for identifying and removing any copyrighted content that appears on their services.Tech firms argue that this would require the use of automatic content filters to detect copyrighted content, which would mean that parodies – and memes – might be caught in the crossfire.Equally controversial is Article 11 – the link tax.

The objective here is to get news aggregator sites – such as Google News – to pay publishers for using snippets of their articles on their platforms. Attempts to bring in similar rules on a national level have already been tried (and have failed) in Spain and Germany. Copyright experts have roundly criticised both articles as unworkable and incompatible with existing EU legislation.Platforms such as Google News control such a significant share of traffic to online publishers, it makes sense that big publishers will be quick to sign royalty-free licensing deals that benefit them bothSo how did such a seemingly flawed directive get passed, last September, by the European Parliament? A statement given by the MEP who played the leading role in shepherding the directive through the vote gives us one clue.“I am very glad that despite the very strong lobbying campaign by the internet giants, there is now a majority in the full house backing the need to protect the principle of fair pay for European creatives,” said the German MEP Axel Voss in the wake of the vote. Of course, what Voss neglected to mention is that – if the European Commission’s lobbying records are anything to go by – it was actually the music and publishing industry lobbyists who were shouting the loudest during the run-up to the vote.But this didn’t stop anti-GAFA triumphalism reigning in the wake of September’s vote. The sad irony is that if the controversial directive ever makes it into law – and right now it is languishing in the EU’s legislative long grass – it will only bolster Google’s current online dominance to the detriment of less well E'established competitors.If online platforms have to put in place filters to check uploads for copyrighted content, Google already has a system it can sell them: content ID. And since platforms such as Google News control such a significant share of traffic to online publishers, it makes sense that big publishers will be quick to sign royalty-free licensing deals that benefit them both. Legislators, take note: even when Silicon Valley loses, it’s still winning.
